So firstly on mobile prepaid I thought you were going to say only a 10% difference between us and our competitors which we actually think that we've done very well in the prepaid market. However the prepaid market has declined which is what you are really alluding to. However we have performed very well in the prepaid market and we're seeing good performance in that business.

We've refocused the business. We've got a dedicated group now in that area and really tidied up the channels. So we're pleased about the growth we've seen and but it is a tough market, but we continue to do very well. Do you want to add anything else on that Gordon, but I think that's pretty much the key things, because Gordon has been driving (1:13:22).

The overall prepaid market, I think, we're just waiting to see the final numbers. It's probably declined half-on-half – on a year-on-year basis by about 7%. And we believe we're growing in a declining market, probably taking the lion's share of volume. I think if we look at the month of December, we probably have moved to a position where we're now number two, where we were in the past number three thereby distant 10 points of revenue market share. So we really have seen some very positive revenue growth in a declining market.

I think we'll see the pull-through of revenue in the second half and the strong pre-pay overall performance in a declining market. We have seen positive net subscriber growth in the half, and if you recall in the prior half we were the only operator to actually to grow our net side of the base and all other competitors declined, and we think that trend will continue... well we're waiting for the final numbers. But we believe that trend will continue for each one as well.

Great. Thanks, Gordon. So let me just quickly readdress the PSTN and Business outlook. 9% down in terms of revenue, but remember ESIO (1:14:50) decline is really nowhere near as pronounced as it has been. As Mark said, we are seeing this rebalance, usage is really the key determinant in terms of that driving down. But as we put these bundled products into the market, we're seeing some good stabilization there. But no, look that's sort of in line with what we anticipated, Laurent. I think you're probably going to see that sort of decline going on just as usage changes but the bundles, churn levels lower, keeping the customers must be our priority as we go through into an NBN world. Do you want to add anything else to that Mark?
Not on PSTN other than the final access determination does have a slight impact as well..
Yeah. That's right. But it's sort of not. So do you want to pick up on – do you want that chart back up or you're okay?
Laurent, can you see the chart? Which number chart is it? The chart on substitution, Henry.
Thanks.

So Laurent, it's important to understand the employee costs have a $126 million hit as a result of lower government bond rates. I won't bore you with the accounting. But basically we discount our forward liabilities for long service leave and workers' comp about a 10-year bond rate. The 10-year bond rate dropped from about 5.21% to 3.67% over the half, so a substantial drop. And so that means we have to restate our provisions, which goes to the expense line. It's non-cash. It's simply balance sheet to P&L, but that did have a significant impact of $126 million. There was also $43 million associated with conversions that were previously in the service contract line, now up in the labor line. So they are the two major elements. It's really important to understand that because the underlying trend is actually quite good.

Right. And Laurent, I'll just give you a little bit more flavor on this because as we bring consultants in, which is all about a very intentional strategy, really build our IT capability. We did not want it external to the company. So you get that sort of move. Over the period and we brought Reach in, iVision in, so we've actually had an increase of 400 people. So when you look at that less the salary increase and you get to a negative 1%, it's actually a very strong result just taking those anomalies out because we do look at this every week, looking at what the dynamics are and of course the NAS business is pulling through some other people as well but we've got to keep driving this. So, yeah, headline, you say, "Gee, what's going on?" I asked the same question but underneath it it's actually a pretty strong story. But if you need more detail on that we can just take you through later on (1:17:35).
The next question from the phones, please.
The next question is from Vikas Gour from Deutsche Bank. Go ahead please, Vikas.

Thanks. Just three questions for me as well. Firstly, the wholesale broadband agreement, just wanted to know what the key issues are from your end and if that's likely to have a major impact on the NBN payments. From a Sensis perspective I was also just trying to get an understanding from the slide, it said it's a three year transition program. Just wanted to know whether you can start to – whether you can expect to see revenue and potentially earnings growth from FY 2015 onwards.
And also lastly on capital management, is it likely to be dependent on current broadband policy? And is political certainty a big caveat on capital management?

Okay. Vikas, right the wholesale broadband agreement. Yeah, look we're making good progress on this and remember it's just the 12 month short term contract that we're just working through at the moment. So we're just tightening up a couple of points there. Stuart Lee's doing a great job. So it's imminent I think but we just need to work through the final bits. So no big drama there. It has no impact at all on the SSU at all. It's just, we've just got to do this, it's just like any other contract we negotiate and we think it's important just to get the settings right as we go forward. Sensis three year transition, and yes, I mean, our hope as we go through this, but it's a big change. And if you look at every Yellow Pages business in the world they have gone through a similar transition and then they get to a flattening of revenues and then they work through their margin improvement.

We've just got to look at the dynamics in the Australian market as we move through to digital and that's why the metro campaign is so important to us, just to see how we're tracking. But if the size of the non-metro campaign are any indication, we think that the three year period is about the right period to start planning for it.
Now in terms of the last question, could you repeat it? I just didn't get all the details.
Capital management, are there any caveats around political certainty or otherwise...

Well, no, it's – first of all, SSU, get that down and done, then we can talk about capital management. And remember we've always said that when we went to the market with the expansion memorandum, we said look there's this natural hedge we have. And so, we're pretty comfortable should there be a change of policy, change of government, change of technology.
We're pretty comfortable as we go forward, but we obviously look at it but let's get the SSU done then the board will decide on capital management and then we'll come forward and so.
We'll take one more question from the phone then we'll come to Tony here.
Thank you. The next question is Brad Clibborn from Credit Suisse. Go ahead, please, Brad.

Hi, good morning, guys. Three questions from me. Just back on Sensis. Even adjusting for the first (1:20:45) timing issues, the EBITDA decline is quite aggressive, so just, if you can just identify where you expect to be able to continue the pull costs out of the business in terms of whether it's labor or other costs, and specifically within labor which areas? On NAS, could you just give us some color as to which products and segments are actually driving the growth there and what you really see is the key opportunity? And on CSL, you spoke about solid growth in terms of subscribers for the half, how does that fit into the portfolio? Would you consider divesting it given the strong results you're seeing there? Thanks.
Okay. So, maybe you can bring the Sensis chart up for me, so I just want to give you some color on the Sensis. So, on...
Andrew, can we bring the charts up please, on Sensis?
Yeah, thanks. The ones we went through. Yeah.

So in terms of the cost out, remember the first half we had a bubble from the end of last year to this year just as we settled in iGen, process all the digital media ads and also the new print ads into the new system. So, we had a big bubble of cost that came through end of last year, first half of this year. And you can already see the action we've taken both at the end of last year and the first month of this half. And you can see that we're working of the labor side there very hard.

We've also taken a lot of the corporate services back into the Telstra. So that's been a big part of our change and we're just driving greater efficiencies and now the productivity is back to the levels before we changed to the iGen product. So there, we are pretty clear on the cost profile for the half and we – by this stage, you know your revenue profile and you know your cost profile in this business. So, you've got pretty clear run through the half. The big question is as you go into Metro for next year. So, and as I said on the chart here which is about the 30% EBITDA decline, which is less than what you've seen in the first half because of timing of revenue recognition. So that's the first one. I'll get Mark to talk about the NAS color.

CSL, wonderful, it's doing very well. When you ask me are we a seller, it always depends at what price. But no, we've got no intention to sell it at this point. It's performing strongly and we'll continue to look at options as we go forward and we want to see if we can grow the portfolio. But again, so you don't in any way misunderstand what I'm saying, we're not about to go and buy big properties throughout Asia. We're looking at organic growth, how we can leverage our assets in Asia to go forward. I want to be very clear about that because sometimes people write things that we're about to do things that we're not. So I hope that gives you some color there. NAS, in terms of the areas of the growing...

I'll throw it to Brendon for some more color. But at the headline product level, managed data networks is growing strongly. Unified comms, another area of growth. Hosting, cloud hosting, another area of growth. We've got a bit of a kick-up with iVision. So iVision's brought some capability in but I'll throw it to Brendon who manages that group to give some more color.

Yes. So just adding to what Mark said so, so very strong growth in intelligent networks, cloud and unified communications. So they're all up very strongly and taking share in those segments. And then we continue to see very strong growth in working with our major corporate clients on taking their internal spend around networks and services and externalizing that to us and working on sort of major integration initiatives. So and if we're looking forward on the pipeline, the pipeline's strong in all of those areas as well.
Okay, come back here to Melbourne.

Yeah. Tony Wilson, Evans and Partners. A couple of questions, Mark, one for you. Just the shift to MRO plans, the big push on those plans has had an accounting impact in terms of profit benefit of the current period and last period. Could you give us an indication of exactly what that benefit is? You made reference to zero dollar plans, but I think that accounting benefit extends to all the MRO plans. And what proportion of funds that are now sold, or plans that are now sold, are actually MRO plans?

And a second question, just in relation to the FOXTEL-Austar merger, if that is to go through, there will be undertakings or certain undertakings placed on the two groups. So I'm just wondering what undertakings or what impact those undertakings could have in terms of your participation in FOXTEL and just how you deal with that in relation to bundling product?

I'll get Mark back to handle the MRO, I think, but just a top level. MRO is a mix. A lot of people think there's some accounting within (1:26:10). It's actually about getting a more balanced portfolio. But let me get Mark to take you through that.

Sure. So, first of all, MRO we've had for 10 years. David and I actually brought MRO into the market 10 years ago at mobile. But what is new is zero dollar MRO. So it's zero dollar MRO, it's about low tens of millions [of dollars] of impact. That's the order of magnitude. So relatively immaterial. In terms of the benefits of MRO, it does allow customers to choose higher-end handsets and make a contribution. So it's an important part of their go-to-market offers. So the way we look at it, the zero dollar which is new, it accounts for, as I said, 3% of total activity. The MRO in total was 23% of total mobile activity. So once again, we have a balance of offers in the market and MRO is just one of those.
Correct. Any undertakings we make, we take very seriously.

Look we obviously wanting FOXTEL to be successful and we think the Austar transaction is in the interests of FOXTEL business. At times, the commission looks at flow on impacts around market dynamics and price to consider the impact of what our position could or could not be. But no, we're very conscious of that and there's nothing there at the moment that we would think constraints either the Telstra side or would constrain the FOXTEL business.

So it's a fine balance but yes we do discuss it a lot, Peter as you'd imagine and Rick's learning all about it already. So but no, at the moment we think that we can hopefully meet the commissioner's requirements and get on with the deal because we think it's in the interests of FOXTEL, the industry and we can move forward.
And where do you think the actual CR (1:28:00) at the moment in terms of the types of questions they're asking you.
Well I know intimately the types of questions they're asking and at the moment we feel comfortable is the answer because it's not really appropriate for me to share.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thanks. We'll go back to the phone lines please.
Thank you. The next question is Sachin Gupta from Nomura. Go ahead please.

Hi. Thanks very much. I just got two questions. Firstly on this 4G/LTE discussion, any indication on how much could it cost for the upgrade or what do you think is a fair price for the spectrum? And also if the 700 megahertz pricing is not compelling, can you guys extend the rollout on the 1800 MHz? I just want to clarify that.
And secondly sorry just go back to the ARPU trends, your wireless broadband ARPUs are down to $32 at the moment. I was wondering any reason why these can't continue to drop further? Thanks.

Okay, Sachin, right. See if I got all of those questions. Firstly, the price of the digital dividend spectrum, we hope as low as possible but it is an auction. So look, we can't comment on that today. The – you can look at global trends, what we've seen in Europe which we – our guys are very good at managing that. So we'll work that one through.

Your question around, if it was too expensive, say we couldn't get access to it. Do we have other options? I'm delighted to say, I think Mike Wright is probably one of the best mobile engineers in the world and I think he always has options. So we will continue to look at that. So one of the things in this industry you never want to be dependent on any one technology or one outcome.

And in terms of ARPU on mobile broadband, as I said before Sachin, there's a whole lot of factors in there. You've got postpaid dongles, you've got prepaid dongles and you've got the tablets. The tablets are running about, what, an $18, $20 ARPU roundabout because a lot of people offload to Wi-Fi. Prepaid is obviously a lot less than what you get on postpaid. Postpaid ARPU is going pretty well. But there is pricing pressure in that market. However, what we're more interested in is actually the profitability per megabyte we carry, a la why we went to LTE. And we're very pleased about how that is performing because one of the things that is more important than anything else, we've got Moore's Law working about, we have to carry more data at a lower cost. It's all about the profitability of that business, and that's what we focus on more than any particular ARPU number. And I'm pleased to say with Warwick Bray, with Mike, we manage this very closely.

Now to give you some color here, I mean it's a big job we've got. The amount of data I think doubled again in the last 12 months on the network. We're managing every cell very tightly within the – so we get good performance right across the network and the network continues to perform exceptionally well relative to any other network so we are very pleased about how that's going. But as we talk through this we can give you some more detail. And if you want anything Mark?

Well just a couple of comments. Thanks David. We exited the full year 30% odd revenue decline – sorry operating decline on that product, so it's actually better than that now and also what's important to me and the company as David said continue to grow both revenue and contributions. So that's how we manage that business.
So I hope that gives you some feel, Sachin.
Yes, thank you.
Next question please.
Thank you. The next question is from Fraser McLeish from RBS. Go ahead please, Fraser.

Thanks very much, two from me. Just firstly on mobile pricing and in other words the mobile pricing environment I guess. You've seen Vodafone obviously raise the price of one of its low end plans, you guys have pulled back a bit on your iPhone subsidies. Is that a signal you think there's a more rational pricing environment out there? That's my first one.
I think we're allowing you three today.

Okay. I'll do that. Second one is around "Project New", just where you are in sort of realizing the cost savings from that ,you know the $456.5 million obviously is a very strong result. Is that the sort of high watermark because you've done the easier stuff? Or can we sort of see savings maybe in that sort of region for a few periods to come?

Okay. I'll take those two then. Look, on mobile pricing, look, we watch it very closely and we think it's important that there – we want it to be a rational market. Three player market, usually that's what you find. However, we've always said that we'll remain competitive. We already, and always have said our coverage and our reliability and the latency on our network is the best, so we sold the premium. But at the moment, we feel like it's steady as you go but every month and every week is a different week. And so you have to be very vigilant, but the size at the moment are reasonable. Do you want to add some in that, Gordon? Gordon's sort of close to the day-to-day.

Yeah. Just in terms of mobile and the growth but also the profitability of mobile, one of the big changes over the last six months or 12 months has been how we managed our mix. And so I think we have some – we've seen a shift to higher value plans. We talked about a significant shift half-on-half at Investor Day where we now see over 71% of our plans that we sell in-market are above the $59 price point. It's really a dramatic shift in the mix. which drives good profitability, good ROI on our overall investment. And I think you'll see a trend towards managing the mix more aggressively by our competitors as well. They're making price adjustments at the lower price points. They're driving less inclusions at the higher price points. So I think we're well positioned to continue some of the momentum we've seen in the first half that we're encouraged by.

And look, the other thing for the first time we've split out our machine-to-machine, it's starting to become not significant but the early signs. We did what, $40 million. So it's going to be about $80 million or $90 million for the full year – very low ARPUs but very high profit. So we think this, the growth in terms of the number of ins or services on the network will continue to grow very quickly and as Gordon rightly said, every product category have got slightly different characteristics. So that's it. I'm not sure that any of the team would say there was any easy low-hanging fruit within Project New. But it has been a lot of hard work but, yes, we've got to continue down this track. I don't know, Robert, do you want to comment at all about the next 12 months? So, I think that we, obviously have a lot more to do and we would hope that we just keep moving at around this rate. We've got to really, because that's part of the nature of our industry as we go forward. Do you want to add anything else to that?
Mark might want to comment on that, not Robert.

There's plenty of opportunity. We see the same momentum going through the second half so it's not all a matter of low hanging fruit, there's still plenty of opportunity. I mean, we see us continuing momentum at a similar rate in the second half.

Yeah. I think that's the big message, Fraser. I think if you talk to anyone inside Telstra, they feel it every day. Simplifying the business, changing processes, doing it differently is a real focus of ours going forward, so more to come.
Thanks. Next question, please.
The next question is Mark McDonnell from BBY. Go ahead please, Mark.

Good morning. Thanks very much for the call. I have three questions about the P&L. Firstly, in the revenue area there was a handy increase in the other sales category and there's a footnote there that says that that includes $58 million from HFC cable usage, $38 million CCP. I'm just wondering if you could clarify that in relation to your broadband investment or for some other factor and whether that's sustainable?

Secondly, in respect to the OpEx, I note the comments, David, where you said you thought labor costs would be able to be reduced, but I note that your employee head count has increased; domestic full-time has increased in each of the last six-months periods and total workforce has increased in the last six months. So, are we looking at a decrease in the total number of employees or change in job function and a reduction in average salaries? Or what are the factors that would lead to a lower labor cost in the context of a higher workforce?

And my third question is in respect of the tax rate. You had an effective tax rate of 31.8% this time compared with 33.1% last time. I'm just wondering if that is due to any one-off factors or is that sustainable or are we going to see the tax rate revert back to something close to 33%?

Right. Thanks, Mark. Let me take number two and then I'll get Mark to look at the other revenue, he can explain, and also the tax rate because the NPAT's up a lot and obviously that's – we didn't highlight that because there's some factors there. Look what I said and I thought I stressed it, it was labor and labor substitution would reduce in absolute terms. I didn't say labor because there's too many moving parts in our business because we bring – sometimes we in-source which goes into the labor line and sometimes we push more out in terms of partners.

So, the only way to really look at productivity and absolute labor is to look at labor and labor substitution because I could come in here and show you a 10% reduction in labor just because I outsourced everything, and that's not true, just like the other way, sometimes the labor, internal labor goes up and yet our labor substitution has gone down. So it's labor, labor substitutions that we are seeing a decline in and is our focus to get absolute decline in year-to-year. So I hope that sort of tidies that one up, because we had what another 400 people join the business in the last half, and there's a whole lot of reasons why. And that'll be a very different scenario in the second half. Now in terms of other revenue and tax rate, I'll let Mark handle that one.

I'll start with tax. The tax line was primarily driven by an underprovision in the prior period, so simply underprovision which gets reflected in this period. And in terms of the revenue, that's the – a long-term agreement we've had in terms of the use of our HFC cable with FOXTEL. It has certain triggers around the revenue share we get from that. And there's nothing more than that in it, so it's basically the existing agreement we have with FOXTEL, where they use of our HFC cable.
And that's been in other prior years too (1:40:05)
Just to be clear, Mark. We've reported that number consistently probably over three or four years.
Yes, it's always there.
So you can get those... You'll be able to get the history of this if you want.
Okay, thanks, Mark. Can we take the next question, please from the phone?
The next question is Justin Diddams from Citi. Go ahead, please, Justin.

Good morning, guys. Just a couple of questions for me, one on the free cash flow. So first half free cash flow $1.7 billion and you've reiterated the guidance. So I just want to know how you're going to get to the $4.5 billion to $5 billion in the second half, whether we're going to see CapEx pull back or there's other – something else we should expect in the second half is question one and then question two, I think I remember David saying that 1.6 billion (sic) [million] mobile net adds last year would be very difficult to achieve again, but it does seem you're on track to that again this year. And I just wondered if you could give us your view on the second half and how you see the mobile market progressing? And then just on the mobile market, I was wondering if you could give us the first quarter, second quarter split so we can dissect the impact of the iPhone 4S in that contribution.

Okay. I'll give a brief comment on cash flow then I'll pass to Mark and I'll get Mark to do number three to the splits of the quarter. But just an overall comment on cash flow. We are very confident about the full year. There's some one-offs in there in our CapEx profile and it's quite consistent with other profiles we've had in half-to-half. But I'll get Mark take us through the detail there. Yes, I do stand corrected. I didn't necessarily say, think that we could do $1.6 billion (sic) [1.6 million], not that I'm forecasting that. Look, the thing that we've decided is that if the market opportunity is there, we'll go after it when we're driving good profitable growth. So that's really the key determinant. At the moment we think that the business is performing well, customers appreciate the value of the network and we've got a great product portfolio in terms of the handsets. So there's many things that are going well for us. So we will – if the opportunity is there, we will go after it. 950,000-odd to 1.6 million, I don't think we're making any forecast. But look, if you look at it, I think that we're tracking pretty well for the second half. The January trading's been pretty strong, which has been good. And so let me get Mark to talk about cash in more detail and the profiling and also the mobile numbers. ForEx had a big impact obviously.

Sure. CapEx, I would look at last year's profile, it was similar. So last year, we in fact were high. CapEx was very high. Cash flow this year once you strip out (1:43:03) as I mentioned earlier. So these sort of things apply. We generally have a run up on that CapEx program around June, which flows into cash in the first few months of the fiscal year. We'd also run up our inventories and debt is in the channel, so as we distribute inventory into our channel late after Christmas, that does impact cash in the first half and also traditionally collections have always been stronger in the second half.
So as David said, we're very confident of the second half profile and you just have to look back to last year to see how that works.
And you're going to look at first and second quarter splits on sub growth, did you have that or do you want to come back to that one?
We'll come back to that later, yeah.
Okay, can we come back to you, Justin, on the – I don't think we've got the numbers here on the split. We didn't publish...
No, we haven't. We haven't talked about it. Justin, I'll give you call later.
Okay we'll pick that right up. But the 4S, we did very well. I mean, there's no question it stimulated the market. If you know when the iPhone 5 is, let us know and we'd like that too.
Next question from the phones, please.
Thank you. The next question is Digby Gilmour from CLSA. Go ahead, please. Digby?

Thanks very much guys. Firstly on Sensis. Can you please give us an indication of what percentage of Sensis revenues are now online in total? And just a concern, six weeks trading post year end, has the revenue run rate improved or maintained?

Secondly, just on EBITDA guidance, from a high level, low-single digit FY 2012 EBITDA growth for fiscal 2012 based on what you just reported implies, the second half EBITDA flat or even slightly down, just wondering in your minds what would drive this? Is this revenue falling away, perhaps the mobile revenue growth falling away, or cost benefits starting to slow or is guidance basically an easy beat?

And then finally, on direct COGS, just wondering, should we expect these to fall away in the second half given the lower termination rates and maybe mobile commission subsidies, et cetera, just any color there around the COGS line would be great? Thank you.

Okay, I'll do one and I'll give Mark numbers two and three on the EBITDA profiling. Firstly, in terms of the digital Yellow and digital White, we would now be – we're probably getting up to 25% of our revenues thereabouts and growing just on double digit, so moving along pretty well. As I said, the more – the better question for trading on Sensis, because it's such a back-end skewed business with the way you put the books out. It's not so much about the revenue flows. It's more about how your non-metro area sales went because that's a better indicator and it's right on our forecast for the year.

So, that, the good thing there is it's traveling as well as we have expected it to. We've still got probably another week just before we close out non-metro. Then we go into metro. So trading is as expected. So that's where we're at with that. So do you want to take EBITDA and COGS?

Yeah. So in terms of the growth profile for EBITDA, it's more about last year than this year. So, last year in the first half we had a write-down of our Octave investment. Second half, we recognized a gain on the Reach integration and we also had a stronger second half performance last year. So obviously coming off a stronger second half of last year and as I said, there was an accounting gain booked in terms of the Reach integration. So that's what really tempers the second half looking at the full year impact.

But we're doing as best aswe can. On the COGS and the question around mobile terminating rights. The COGS question is actually, Gordon, (1:47:00) and I can talk about the other bigger thing of COGS. So COGS is really driven by what opportunities are in the market. And as we've said before, if the market opportunity is there, we'll spend the money, if it's not, we'll pull back. But Mark, our terminating rates change because that's the difference from the second half.

Yes, our second half, it's around about $78 million impact in terms of the revenue impact. We get slightly positive on the EBITDA line because of we're a net outpayer. So that all is a second half impact. So obviously the revenue line will be tempered and we'll have a slight kick on the EBITDA line, and that is excluded for guidance purposes.
So that's why we're saying single digit on both, low single digit.
Thanks, David, I think we have two questions left from the phone. Please.
Thank you. The next question is Sameer Chopra from Merrill Lynch. Go ahead please, Sameer.

Good morning, Sameer Chopra from Merrill Lynch. I had three questions. First one, David, there was some press report through Jan talking about the dividend opportunity at Telstra. And I was wondering, has the board already made up their mind on capital management and is it just a question of announcing into the market once you've completed the – once ACCC's given you approval? So that's kind of first question, if the board's already decided and you're just waiting for the deal to get closed.

Second one is just on depreciation. Depreciation has been running ahead of CapEx. I think it's just down to show signs of maybe falling back down towards CapEx? And I was just wondering if this is now a trend we should expect? Are we going to see D&A get towards $3.5 billion-type level? And the last one is just on Mobiles if you can perhaps describe where you're seeing your strongest demand? I was trying to figure out at which sort of price point, where is the kind of the sweet spot for Telstra?

Sameer on the dividend what the position is that we have confirmed the dividend for two years. There was a speculative piece written of special dividend that was – the word special was never mentioned in the interview so I'll be very clear about that. The board has reviewed capital management. They have made no decision on capital management. It is subject to the SSU. But it is a constant topic on the board agenda as you would expect but no decision has been made on that. That will be subject to getting SSU done and then moving forward but well across the detail. Mark, do you want to handle depreciation?

Okay just on D&A, we do expect the current level to remain in the short term. We are coming off the back of some significant CapEx three or four years ago in the transformation so in the short term, we're seeing D&A at similar levels.

And then where is the sweet spot with Mobiles? Well that's a big question, Sameer. Look, it's – the network coverage and the capability of the network continues to be such a major differentiator for us and that's what we continue to invest in. And so it sort of touches just about all the product offerings we have in the market. We have as Gordon talked about we had good performance in prepaid. We've had a strong 4S performance. We're having strong performance right across the smartphones. I think I'm not sure I'm just looking at Gordon, are we putting out anything on the plan types sort or about where we're – at the volume we're seeing. I think we've got very strong on 4S as we go forward. Mobile broadband going well. I think that sort of probably gives you enough of an indication there.
Okay.
But pretty much across the portfolio really, it has been good. So I think that's it Sameer.
Thanks.
We'll take the last question please, operator.
Thank you. The last question is Laurent Horrut from JPMorgan. Go ahead, Laurent.

Thank you very much for taking another one. I just wanted to touch on the capital structure. I've noticed in the half, the debt – then gross debt actually has increased quite a bit. Not that I think you're over-geared by any standard. But it has gone up and your leverage ratio has gone up a bit. Just a general question on, how do you think about the level of debts in the migration to NBN? Would you want the overall sort of level of gearing to go down? Are you comfortable with that level of gearing going through NBN?

And a subsequent question on that is, where are you on franking? I think you've got a negative balance of $89 million as of December. Are you still having to prepay tax to fully frank the dividend and if so, for how long? Thank you very much.
I think Mark's got that one on the capital structure. I mean the debts up a little bit and...

So the debt profile basically follows our cash profile. So obviously first half cash is not as strong as second half. So you'd expect some rebalance there. In terms of our parameters, they are set by the board, but we're very comfortable with those parameters. They're very important in the current environment for us to maintain an A credit rating. It does give us access to capital markets bringing such a strong balance sheet, underwriting such as that. So, we're comfortable with that and the board will continue to reassess as we move through the NBN phase. And just on franking, we are – our franking balance we manage closely and we are forecasting a fully franked dividend or guiding a fully franked dividend this year and expect similar going forward. So...
Yeah. So franking very important and – okay so...
That's everything. I don't know if you have any closing comments, David.
Okay. No look, I think I've said it all. Thanks for coming. We've got a more lot more work to do, but it's pleasing first half results and we'll keep at it. So, thanks very much.
